trans-unit.source: Assigning administrator roles in Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Assigning administrator roles in Azure AD

trans-unit.source: A topic that explains what admin roles are available with Azure AD and how to assign them.
trans-unit.target: A topic that explains what admin roles are available with Azure AD and how to assign them.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the size of your company, you may want to designate several administrators who serve different functions.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the size of your company, you may want to designate several administrators who serve different functions.

trans-unit.source: These administrators will have access to various features in the Azure portal and, depending on their role, will be able to create or edit users, assign administrative roles to others, reset user passwords, manage user licenses, and manage domains, among other things.
trans-unit.target: These administrators will have access to various features in the Azure portal and, depending on their role, will be able to create or edit users, assign administrative roles to others, reset user passwords, manage user licenses, and manage domains, among other things.

trans-unit.source: It's important to understand that a user who is assigned an admin role will have the same permissions across all of the cloud services that your organization has subscribed to, regardless of whether you assign the role in the Office 365 portal, or in the Azure portal, or by using the Azure AD module for Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: It's important to understand that a user who is assigned an admin role will have the same permissions across all of the cloud services that your organization has subscribed to, regardless of whether you assign the role in the Office 365 portal, or in the Azure portal, or by using the Azure AD module for Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: The following administrator roles are available:
trans-unit.target: The following administrator roles are available:

trans-unit.source: Billing administrator: Makes purchases, manages subscriptions, manages support tickets, and monitors service health.
trans-unit.target: Billing administrator: Makes purchases, manages subscriptions, manages support tickets, and monitors service health.

trans-unit.source: Global administrator: Has access to all administrative features.
trans-unit.target: Global administrator: Has access to all administrative features.

trans-unit.source: The person who signs up for the Azure account becomes a global administrator.
trans-unit.target: The person who signs up for the Azure account becomes a global administrator.

trans-unit.source: Only global administrators can assign other administrator roles.
trans-unit.target: Only global administrators can assign other administrator roles.

trans-unit.source: There can be more than one global administrator at your company.
trans-unit.target: There can be more than one global administrator at your company.

trans-unit.source: Password administrator: Resets passwords, manages service requests, and monitors service health.
trans-unit.target: Password administrator: Resets passwords, manages service requests, and monitors service health.

trans-unit.source: Password administrators can reset passwords only for users and other password administrators.
trans-unit.target: Password administrators can reset passwords only for users and other password administrators.

trans-unit.source: Service administrator: Manages service requests and monitors service health.
trans-unit.target: Service administrator: Manages service requests and monitors service health.

trans-unit.source: To assign the service administrator role to a user, the global administrator must first assign administrative permissions to the user in the service, such as Exchange Online, and then assign the service administrator role to the user in the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: To assign the service administrator role to a user, the global administrator must first assign administrative permissions to the user in the service, such as Exchange Online, and then assign the service administrator role to the user in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: User administrator: Resets passwords, monitors service health, and manages user accounts, user groups, and service requests.
trans-unit.target: User administrator: Resets passwords, monitors service health, and manages user accounts, user groups, and service requests.

trans-unit.source: Some limitations apply to the permissions of a user management administrator.
trans-unit.target: Some limitations apply to the permissions of a user management administrator.

trans-unit.source: For example, they cannot delete a global administrator or create other administrators.
trans-unit.target: For example, they cannot delete a global administrator or create other administrators.

trans-unit.source: Also, they cannot reset passwords for billing, global, and service administrators.
trans-unit.target: Also, they cannot reset passwords for billing, global, and service administrators.

trans-unit.target: Can do

trans-unit.source: Cannot do
trans-unit.target: Cannot do

trans-unit.source: The global administrator has access to all administrative features.
trans-unit.target: The global administrator has access to all administrative features.

trans-unit.source: By default, the person who signs up for an Azure subscription is assigned the global administrator role for the directory.
trans-unit.target: By default, the person who signs up for an Azure subscription is assigned the global administrator role for the directory.

trans-unit.source: Only global administrators can assign other administrator roles.
trans-unit.target: Only global administrators can assign other administrator roles.

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal, click Active Directory, and then click on the name of your organization’s directory.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal, click Active Directory, and then click on the name of your organization’s directory.

trans-unit.source: On the Users page, click the display name of the user you want to edit.
trans-unit.target: On the Users page, click the display name of the user you want to edit.

trans-unit.source: Select the Organizational Role drop-down menu, and then select the administrator role that you want to assign to this user, or select User if you want to remove an existing administrator role.
trans-unit.target: Select the Organizational Role drop-down menu, and then select the administrator role that you want to assign to this user, or select User if you want to remove an existing administrator role.

trans-unit.source: In the Alternate Email Address box, type an email address.
trans-unit.target: In the Alternate Email Address box, type an email address.

trans-unit.source: This email address is used for important notifications, including password self-reset, so the user must be able to access the email account whether or not the user can access Azure.
trans-unit.target: This email address is used for important notifications, including password self-reset, so the user must be able to access the email account whether or not the user can access Azure.

trans-unit.source: Select Allow or Block to specify whether to allow the user to sign in and access services.
trans-unit.target: Select Allow or Block to specify whether to allow the user to sign in and access services.

trans-unit.source: Specify a location from the Usage Location drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: Specify a location from the Usage Location drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: When you have finished, click Save.
trans-unit.target: When you have finished, click Save.
